page.title: 12Sewage Works
page.content: Meltham sewage works was opened on the 17th of September 1973. It deals with sewage from Meltham and the village of Helme. It can cope with 3.3 million gallons of raw sewage a day when required. The sewage is first filtered and then goes into 2 primary settling tanks where the solids settle into the bottom. From the primary tanks the sewage goes into eight biological filter tanks where the insects eat the sewage. These tanks are 6 to 7 feet deep and the water is distributed around the top of the tanks by jets. This process is repeated in what are called secondary biological treatment tanks. When this treatment is completed the water is released into Hall Dyke. The sludge that is left in the primary settling tanks is taken away and turned into fertilizer.
